In the philosophy of Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari, the concept of minor literature is closely related to the idea of deterritorialization. A minor literature is a literature produced by a minority group that resists the dominant culture and its dominant language.

According to Deleuze and Guattari, minor literature is characterized by its resistance to reterritorialization, or the attempt to reassert the dominance of the dominant culture. Minor literature is a form of deterritorialization, as it disrupts the dominant language and its associated meanings and values, and creates new connections and meanings.

For Deleuze and Guattari, minor literature is a key site of political and social resistance, as it allows minority groups to assert their own identities and to challenge the dominant culture. Minor literature can take many forms, including literature written in a minority language, literature produced by marginalized groups, and literature that challenges traditional literary forms and conventions.

Overall, the concept of minor literature is closely tied to the idea of deterritorialization and the process of becoming, as it involves the creation of new identities and ways of being in the world that challenge the dominant culture and its power structures.
